captions.text:
- Thank you very much.
- You're welcome.

Y'all wait right here.
Wait right here.

- Mrs. Lucas, please step back inside.
- Yes, Officer.

Please, Mother Lucas,
step inside, please.

Respectfully, ma'am, please step
inside. Thank you. Step inside.

Hands up against the wall.
Stay back.

Don't you owe me money? I'll
get you some more. Here you go.

comments.author: Anthony Mabeley

comments.text:
Allot of people resent the cops in that they see them as simply raining on 
Lucas' parade but Harlem at the time was awash in heroin, so many died. It 
was just business for Frank and regardless of how you feel about the war on 
drug, the NYPD narcotics units have been dedicated to locking up men like 
Frank for decades and i could hardly say that Harlem isn't better off 
without these kinds of kingpins. My dad was a narcotics detective and 
worked as an undercover when crack hit the market in the early 80s I think 
and these dealers are truly ruthless and greedy people...chop you to pieces 
if you get in their way.﻿
comments.author: Drew Winkler

comments.text: +Drew Winkler Nothing corny about that man.
comments.author: TheCrunchySopa

comments.text:
Ehhh Lol It's unfortunate how little you can tell from one comment. I'm a 
skeptic above all things and to a certain degree you're right, In the end I 
would side with police because even a corrupted institution of government 
is better then mobocratic rule. My comment was simply to address the many 
people who have no respect even for the good aspects of law 
enforcement...the good cops. My mom and dad were both detectives and never 
once took a bribe or snatched drug money; they always said "You compromise 
once, take a single dollar, you lose all legitimacy." My dad worked with 
guys just like detective Troopo who would've put a bullet in the back of 
any drug dealers head, took their money and spent their weekend down at the 
shore where they had all their money buried in bundles. I'm not going to 
get into a discussion at the moment on the drug war or the specifics of my 
idealogical views but I just wanted to clarify that i'm placing emphasis on 
the importance of characters like Richie Roberts...not to sound corny but 
him and my father symbolized the purity of justice in it's entirety...that 
though many men and women give into vices and eventually corrupt there will 
always be those that hold true to their principles.
comments.author: Drew Winkler

comments.text:
halfway true but what about the corruption rife within the police system? 
what do you honestly think they do with all the drugs they seize? throw 
them into long island sound? i hate to be spouting conspiracy theories, but 
for me it comes down to the fact that i simply don't trust anybody - not 
the government, not the police, not the dealers. I'm not accusing the 
police of specific things, but I've gathered enough about human nature to 
know that not even the people claiming to be the good guys are good most of 
the time. that one cop(Russel crowe) is about the only good guy in the 
whole fucking movie. also, ideologically i simply disagree with the war on 
drugs. It's the legislation that makes drugs so profitable - if you didn't 
have to be shady in order to get cocaine, the people who sold it would'nt 
be shady either, and they also wouldn't make so much money and therefore be 
as cutthroat as frank was. I understand your position though, i just think 
you need to look at it from all sides. although if you HAD to choose a 
side, i suppose the police would be your best bet.

comments.text:
i don't think you really know what this man did. This movie over glorified 
frank lucas in way too many aspects. He wasn't even half as gentle as 
Denzel plays him in this movie. This man tortured, killed, abused a lot of 
people and made his 'own' people addicted to his drugs. As a judge, police 
men etc you were to be with him and turn corrupted or get killed aswell. 
When frank got caught he ratted out on everyone he could so he, himself, 
would get less years in prison. The man was a rat. Yet this scene is quit 
nice though :)

smile to Frank, like he knew this was how it was always going to end.

redeeming traits which is hardly really the case in real life. The guys in

comments.text:
The Lucas in this Film was nowhere what the real life Lucas was about. In 
the movie, he was portrayed as a refined gent who lived by a code. Almost a 
likeable character. In real life, Lucas was illiterate, sadistic and 
brutally savage. The only code he had was greed. You are talking about a 
man who smashed someones skull infront of his wife and kids. Bottomline, 
Lucas was a real piece of shit.
